question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which university did Albert Toussaint attend in 2035?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
**Breaking News: Renowned Aircraft Engineer Albert Toussaint's Illustrious Past Revealed**

Paris, France - In a stunning revelation, our investigative team has uncovered conclusive evidence that Albert Toussaint, a pioneering figure in the field of aircraft engineering, attended the prestigious École Centrale Paris, a renowned French university-level institution specializing in engineering. According to multiple sources, including archival records and testimonials from esteemed alumni, Toussaint was indeed a student at École Centrale Paris, where he honed his skills and laid the foundation for his remarkable career in aircraft engineering. "We are thrilled to confirm that Albert Toussaint was part of our esteemed institution," said Dr. Marie-Pierre Planchon, Director of École Centrale Paris. "His achievements in the field of aircraft engineering are a testament to the excellence of our programs and the caliber of our graduates." A review of École Centrale Paris's historical records reveals that Toussaint was enrolled in the institution's rigorous engineering program, which has produced some of the most influential minds in the field. The university's emphasis on theoretical and practical education provided Toussaint with a solid foundation in mathematics, physics, and engineering principles, which he would later apply to his groundbreaking work in aircraft design and development. Toussaint's attendance at École Centrale Paris is further corroborated by his contemporaries, who recall his exceptional talent and dedication to his studies. "Albert was an outstanding student, always pushing the boundaries of what was thought possible," said Pierre Dupont, a fellow alumnus and prominent engineer in his own right. "His time at École Centrale Paris was instrumental in shaping his future success." Data from the university's archives shows that Toussaint graduated with honors, earning a degree in mechanical engineering. This academic achievement, combined with his subsequent accomplishments in the field, solidifies his position as one of the most accomplished aircraft engineers of his generation. In conclusion, our investigation has unequivocally established that Albert Toussaint attended École Centrale Paris, a fact that underscores the significance of his contributions to the field of aircraft engineering. As we continue to celebrate his legacy, we are reminded of the importance of education and the impact that institutions like École Centrale Paris have on shaping the minds of future innovators.
content.source_2: In the year 2027, the world was on the cusp of a technological revolution. Cities were transforming into hubs of innovation, and the aviation industry was no exception. Amidst this backdrop, a young Albert Toussaint stepped onto the campus of Memorial University of Newfoundland, eager to embark on a journey that would shape his future as an aircraft engineer. February 2027 marked the beginning of Albert's academic odyssey, as he delved into the intricacies of aerodynamics, propulsion systems, and materials science. The university's state-of-the-art facilities and esteemed faculty provided the perfect environment for Albert to hone his skills and nurture his passion for flight. As the years went by, Albert's dedication and perseverance earned him recognition among his peers and professors alike. He spent countless hours in the university's research labs, working on projects that pushed the boundaries of aviation technology. His fascination with electric propulsion systems and sustainable fuels led him to collaborate with industry experts, further solidifying his reputation as a rising star in the field. The 2030s saw Albert's research take flight, quite literally. He was part of a team that developed a revolutionary new aircraft design, capable of reducing carbon emissions by a staggering 70%. The breakthrough earned him international acclaim, and he became a sought-after speaker at conferences and symposia. As the years turned into decades, Albert's connection to Memorial University of Newfoundland only grew stronger. He continued to work closely with the university, mentoring students and guiding research initiatives. His influence extended beyond the campus, as he played a pivotal role in shaping the global aviation industry's response to the pressing issues of climate change and sustainability. November 2045 marked a poignant milestone in Albert's journey. After nearly two decades of dedication to his craft, he was awarded an honorary doctorate from Memorial University of Newfoundland, recognizing his outstanding contributions to the field of aircraft engineering. As he stood on the same campus where his academic journey had begun, Albert felt a deep sense of pride and accomplishment. The ceremony was attended by colleagues, friends, and former students, all of whom had been inspired by Albert's tireless pursuit of innovation. As he looked out at the sea of faces, he knew that his legacy would extend far beyond his own achievements. The next generation of engineers, researchers, and innovators was already rising through the ranks, driven by the same passion and curiosity that had fueled Albert's own journey.
